Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Trunk-Supporting Exoskeleton System for Workers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to improve the lives of workers who bend and stoop while performing their jobs. These activities lead to back injuries which account of 36% of work place injuries. This project will result in an assistive technology to reduce injuries in these workers. There are many workers in shipbuilding and construction sites who perform tasks which cannot be assisted by available technology. Robotics and automation fields do not have solutions in the near horizon to automate these tasks. Therefore, workers are an essential part of these industries. The technology proposed here will make the workers? environment much more pleasant, prevent them from getting disabled and maintain their quality of life. As back injuries cost the US alone 20 billion dollars annually in direct and indirect costs, the technology proposed will not only benefit workers but also employers. Addressing a pain point that costs billions of dollars globally each year gives this project strong commercial potential. The evaluations performed during this project will reveal the technology?s effect on workers? back. This will create an opportunity for other institutions to investigate fundamentals of human back pain or back injuries.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 2 project will improve the lives of workers and reduce financial burden on companies by developing a Trunk Support Exoskeleton (TSE) to reduce back injuries in workers caused by stooping and bending. Back injuries account for a large number of work place injuries. The goal of this project is to develop technologies based on user and customer recommendations, issues encountered during field evaluation, and experimentally evaluate the technology. The tasks include analysis, design and evaluation to reduce separation between the exoskeleton and the user, experiments and design to ease workers during prolonged low angle stooping and determining the requirements for walking while bending. It is expected that these features will make the technology more attractive and useable to users and customers. In addition, to evaluating the technology to validate the features above, experiments to quantify the performance of the technology during activities similar to those that workers would encounter will be performed. It is expected that the technology will reduce the participants? strain on their lower back without reducing their performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
US Bionics evaluated and made improvements to the trunk support exoskeleton (TSE) technology, commercially known as backX. The TSE has been developed to support workers who perform repetitive stooping and lifting tasks. When worn by users, the TSE is designed to reduce the muscle activity at the erector spinae, hence the risk of back injuries at the L5 S1 vertebra.  The TSE achieves this using a torque generator which produces a supporting torque at the user’s hip and which is  transfered to the user’s chest and thighs.  A critical aspect for the success of this technology is its ability to distinguish between walking and stooping by determining the absolute angle of the torso using a purely mechanical sensor. This lends itself to a versatile technology which is robust for a variety of industries while being low cost and effective.

During Phase II, the TSE was adapted to reduce the separation between the user and the exoskeleton during stooping, making the device safer to use in confined spaces. The device was also adapted to be used with a construction safety harness, allowing workers who are required to use the construction safety harness to use the TSE in conjunction with the safety harness. A new exoskeleton donning apparatus was also developed to facilitate use with the safety harness  and allows for quick donning and doffing. Features were added to the exoskeleton system to tune the angle at which support starts and to permit support when the wearer is substantially upright (low angle), which is required for tasks such as table work. To evaluate the requirements for low angle bending, an apparatus wireless transmitting data from three IMU’s placed at the cervical, thoracic and lumber sections of the wearer’s spine was developed. Various strategies were explored to create a trunk support technology which permits walking while bending, i.e. allowing the user to take a step while the trunk is supported. Various apparatus were developed to test and improve the life the commercial passive backX technology. The result of this work has resulted in a TSE technology which can last more than 275,000 cycles of repetitive loading. Several improvements were also made to reduce the device weight and reduce heat felt by the user, which are critical to the usability of the technology.

Evaluation of the technology with 10 participants, weighing 144lbs+/- 23lbs and 68.0inch+/-4.1 inches tall, showed that all participants were able to sustain stooped posture with the TSE and expressed a lower rate of perceived exertion.  The average percent increase in time stooped was 87%. The lowest percentage increase in time was about 8.24%, and the highest percentage increase was 288.33%. No trends were found between user weight, user height and in increase in stoop time. Variations in the results from participants of similar height and weight is most likely a result of different levels of muscle development which is not accounted for in experiment. This shows that for optimal results, the TSE should be tunable across various users.

Dynamic lift task with six participants were conducted and muscle activation was measured in the 4 muscles (Left and Right Thoracic and Lumbar Erector Spinae Muscles). Data was separated into two activities: lowering to the ground and picking up the weight.  Overall, the TSE successfully reduces the muscle activity in the spine during dynamic tasks. On average, three muscle groups - LTES, RLES, and the LLES - showed reduction in activity with the exoskeleton. RTES was the only muscle group that showed an increase in activity with the exoskeleton during the lower to ground activity. The RTES data is skewed by the results of one participant who displayed a large increase in activity for this muscle group throughout the experiment with the exoskeleton. This may be due to sensor data corrupted due to perturbation of the electrode.

A powered exoskeleton prototype for future commercialization was developed, as part of the TECP supplemental funding. The device was evaluated with 9 adult participants. The participants’ heart rate and Borg rating were measured and recorded. An average reduction of heart rate across subjects was 17.30+/-6.81%. Six of 9 participants showed a reduced heart rate, all participants expressed a lower Borg rating. The average percent increase for three participants was 5.80+/-1.81%. This suggests that a powered exoskeleton technology can be useful in reducing effort of the user.
